												After completing this game on the hardest difficulty, I can say, that this is the only game that has a similar gameplay to the Hitman franchise. And if it didn't had an unlimited save option on the last difficulty, it was going to be a lot harder than any of the Hitman games. This game is definitly not for everyone. It is one of the hardest stealth games ever made and shooting your way out is impossible on most of the missions. The game has the wonderful stealth feauture of hiding in plain sight by using different disguises to infiltrate enemy areas. But most of the places are so crowded, that you will find it very hard to remain undetected, even if you take an unique disguise. Getting a disguise is not easy, enemies are hard to be distracted most of the times and after getting distracted, they can become very unpredictable, so you have to be very patient. Things I liked about the game are:+ this is a pure stealth game that combines a lot of elements from other stealth games+ disguises work significantly well, as long as you don't do anything suspicious;+ things like running, crouching or crawling are suspicious, so you cannot act strange in front of your enemy and hope you can get away with it;+ in order for you disguise to work, as a Russian spy, you must only carry enemy German weapons or they will detect you;+ disguises work only if they are acquired after sedating, strangling or stunning an enemy, which means you cannot shoot someone, take his clothes and expect to fool someone else, while the outfit is covered in blood;+ if enemies get alerted after sounding an alarm, like when they found an unconscious body for example, this will automatically mean you can no longer use stealth as an onption because enemies know there is something very wrong with the situation and won't be fooled again. So you must be stealthy all the time, in order to complete most of the missions;+ you have a lot tools at your disposal like chloroform for sedating, strangling wire, pliers, knifes, pitlocks, explosives, snipers an other other guns and most of the times, you can choose what you need the at the start of every mission; + the minimap and the detection meter are very helpful to complete the mission;+ you have a rating system that monitors your playstyle like in the Hitman franchiseThings I didn't like about the game are:- you don't have that much of a freedom like in the Hitman titles;- they can detect you too easily at times, especially when enemies tend to stare at you for no reason.- characters seem to be communicating with each other, but you can never hear real actual conversations- the story is very weak, so if you are looking for a good plot in the WW2 era and a motive to complete the levels to see what happens next, this is not the case- the character you play as is also too plain. You won't hear him say anything during the missions and you won't find him interesting at all like Agent 47 from the Hitman games.- the game was not polished and it has some technical issues Overall, this game was not fully developed. It has some very interesting and challenging gameplay and most of the times, it surpasses the gameplay of other stealth games especially in realism, but due to the fact that the game was made with a low budget, it wasn't developed to be a top-selling title. I only recommend this game to people who really enjoy playing stealth games, especially Hitman fans.

												You are a Soviet counterintelligence agent reliving his memories of sabotage / assassination assignments for SMERSH through flashbacks during an interrogation. The storyline is scattered, as it features select important missions from the spy's CV. Each mission is thus standalone and the main character remains the mysterious strong & silent type. The graphics and controls remind me a lot of Mafia 1 and Max Payne 1 and 2. The shooting accuracy is very messy (not smooth). The game is undemanding and runs smoothly even on older / weaker rigs. Despite it being set in WWII, you won't get that "nazi bashing" feel you get with most games set in that era. DTS is a long enough (will take you 10-12 hours to comlete), stealth-oriented game, so you get lots of rewards for acting qietly - infiltrating enemy compounds, silently disposing of bodies and walking around in enemy uniforms, for the obtainment of which you get a rich array of tools (strangling cord, cloroform, poison, throwing knives, silenced weapons, distraction tools and opportunities, whistling, etc) and you get a rating for your work at the end of each mission.A lot of people and gaming magazines claim the game is overly difficult, and it is not due to the quality of AI. As a matter of fact, the game is difficult mostly due to their quantity. Some missions are literally spammed with civvies and soldiers (who are immune to spatial awareness) to the point where you can't reach your objective on time. Don't get me wrong, even on the easy difficulty, the AI has excellent sight, hearing and identifying capabilities. The higher up you go in uniform, the less suspicion you arouse. Enemies will also recognize foreign weapons and backpacks. Trigger an alarm and you'll have to redo a whole section. Save, save, save. I normally have around 7-10 saves per mission and each mission is about an hour long, mostly because of unknown variables, such as random civvies / soldiers walking in, or you walking in on an uncomfortable set of enemies. You'll spend a lot of time scheming and waiting for an opportunity to strike and hide a body, or a window to run past a diplomat, pick his safe and replace his documents. Compared to other stealth games like Splinter Cell, Death to Spies is more "wooden" and realistic in terms of the human limitations your character has - get in trouble once and it's over. He can't even climb stuff other than ladders. He's just a regular guy, and that makes fooling an entire enemy base such a rewarding experience.

Pros:* Interesting level design* Solid Hitman-esque gameplay* Well thought out design requiring patience and creativity to succeedCons:* Voice acting is not the best.* You only end up really using 4 weapons for the majority of the game.* Less than streamlined HUD and inventory management (akin to DayZ).* Graphics, however serviceable, look a bit dated.How Long To Beat?~13 hours on normal difficulty.Review:Not since "Hitman: Blood Money" have I played a game in the genre that just felt so perfect in terms of what it offers. However, that's not to say it was without flaws though, because there were definitely some things that were less than stellar, and I did run into a few bugs here and there with getting stuck in doors when operating them, forcing me to reload. Luckily it only happened a handful of times throughout the game, and since there are no save restrictions (there's even a quick save), it didn't take much time to get back to where I was, which made it, at worst, a minor annoyance.You play the role of a Russian KGB agent, who is sent on all types of missions ranging from either capturing or assassinating German officers, performing acts of espionage, rescuing allies, to even blowing up places of strategic importance. The game is split up into 10 missions, each lasting anywhere from around 45 minutes to 2 hours depending on the difficulty setting, and style of play. There's a great amount of mission variety, making sure you never get too comfortable with a certain type or style of environment. The missions, while appearing quite linear are very open-ended in how you go about achieving your goals, and it's never about just meeting one objective either. In fact there are always several ways to succeed. To give an example of this, one mission has you infiltrating an internment camp where your overall objective is to rescue a friendly agent. You have no idea where in the camp he is though, so the first order of business is to obtain that knowledge. To do that you need to go to the officer quarters in the middle of the camp, which is something you can't just walk into wearing your Russian uniform, or carrying your Russian made weapons and backpack, as you'd just get shot on sight. So you stalk a patrol to a quiet place, where after having disposed of them, you slip into one of their uniforms. However you still can't just stroll right in, because there are certain types of German personnel who can identify you as not being one of theirs, and this will once again get you shot on sight, so after finding a weak spot in the fence surrounding the base somewhere, you cut a hole giving you access to the base itself. Once inside, you quickly locate the officer barracks, only to find a guard denying you entrance, telling you that someone of your rank has nothing to do inside. This means you need to find an officer and acquire his uniform in order to gain access, which is easier said than done. Once you've done that though, you're then able to access the officer barracks where you can find the correct papers, meaning you now know the agent's location. From here there are several ways to rescue him. One way is to stay in the officer uniform and obtain some access papers that'll allow you to escort the prisoner to the exercise yard, and go from there. Alternatively you can acquire a doctor's uniform, enabling you to escort the prisoner to the medical station, and go from there. You can of course also try to just kill everyone in the camp who gets in your way without getting caught in the act. However you choose to go about it, each way presents its own obstacles, which makes for an often very tense and always interesting game session.When a mission is completed, you're graded on your efforts by use of a scoring system. Did you take your time, and chose to subdue the least amount of enemies using only non lethal methods such as chloroform, or were you pressed for time and chose to not leave anyone breathing along the way? Furthermore, were you able to hide the bodies well enough so that they weren't discovered later on? Were you noticed, and if so, did you manage to kill the enemies before they could rush off to sound the alarm? All these things, and more, end up giving you a final score alongside information about how long it took you to complete the mission, though in truth it's all a bit irrelevant, and is really just for personal enjoyment, since as long as you complete the mission in any way, you'll still progress to the next one. There's no gear to purchase or leveling to be done.The game is well worth your time, though keep in mind that it was released in 2007, so adjust your expectations accordingly. However, if you're the type of gamer who can look past dated graphics and some issues, I'd very much recommend it, assuming you're a fan of the genre.Personal Notes:I happened upon this game by pure accident. The only thing I knew about this game before buying it, was from what I could gather from about 5 minutes of gameplay footage on youtube, showing off what looked to be a good Hitman clone. I'm really glad I decided to take a chance on it without doing a ton of research first, because there's something to be said for going in without a lot of preconceived notions.I hope you found the review helpful. Should you have any feedback - positive or negative - please don't hesitate to leave a comment.

 This game is overall very good.   It is very different from your average WWII game which there's a lot of shooting.  This game involves careful planning and stealth.  You will find yourself dead very quickly if you start shooting.  I will discuss this game under these heading:LEVELS: There are 10 levels in total.  Most of them take at least 1 hour to complete.  The levels include; a German concentration camp, a British hotel, an American military base and a German military school.  A detailed tutorial mission can be done at the start of the game.DISGUISES: Disguises are an important element of this game.  Most levels you start off in Soviet military camouflage clothes.  German soldiers will immediately start shooting at you until you get a disguise.  There are different disguises available.  A German soldier is the most basic disguise.  Most German soldiers will not bother you but higher ranks may see through your disguise.  Some levels require you to get officer's uniforms, staff's clothes (e.g. a chef) or a worker's clothes.WEAPONS: Before you start each level you can fully customise your equipment.  You can carry a shoulder, side and a knife weapon.  Main weapons include MP40s, MP44s and Stens.  Many pistols are also available.  The silenced pistol is he most useful.  Knifes can be carried - they can be used at close range or thrown.  For silent kills you are equipped with a choke cord and chloroform.  You can also punch people, although this is nosier.VEHICLES: Vehicles can be driven in some missions.  Trucks, motorbikes and cars can be driven.UI: You can swap between a main map and a mini-map.  You can use the + and - keys to zoom in and out.  The AI are shown as green, yellow, red and grey icons; green meaning no suspicion of you, yellow - vary (don't stay around these guys too long!), red - alert, usually if they see you they will raise the alarm and grey - civilians.  A suspicion meter appears at the top of the screen when guards are suspicious of you.  If this fills the alarm will be raised.AI: There are many different types/appearances of AI people, though they aren't great.  Once you start shooting they tend to run around crazily until they compose themselves.  Mostly they're OK though.Sound: The sound is good in this game.  German music can be heard coming from gramophones and the environmental sound are good.  The AI are pretty wordless.  This is improved in the sequel Moment of Truth (they say ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to you if you're dressed as an officer!)OTHER: You can pick locks, spy through keyholes, sabotage functions to distract attention away and more.This is a great game I recommend you buy it (wait for a sale somewhere - and get the Gold Edition, it works out cheaper).  If you like a game with lots of pace and action this may not be the game for you.

												I want to make this very clear before I properly start this review: I have put this as "Not Recommended" as it is definitely not recommended for the average gamer - for most, it will be too frustrating and infuriating to last much longer than an hour. However, if you are a big stealth fan like myself, then you will get some enjoyment out of this game. That enjoyment is limited though, and I'll explain.If you've played the Hitman series, Death to Spies should instantly remind you of it. You're walking around open areas with multiple paths and disguises are a vital aspect of the gameplay. The difference is that Hitman does it a lot better. The disguise system in this game is a strange beast - you can wear multiple disguises in each level, usually 2 or 3, and usually one will be "better" than the other - as in, there will be less "red" enemies who are able to see through your disguise. The whole thing doesn't really make sense - some enemies, for whatever unexplained reason, know you're a spy. I've completed the game from start to finish and I still don't really get it.This game is also mercilessly difficult and frustrating. I won't say "challenging" - because that implies you have to think deeply and strategically about what you're actually doing. Most of the time, you'll have quick save and quick load at the ready, doing things in hope rather than guile and seeing if they actually work. The game leaves you very little hints or clues about how to achieve your objectives, which I know some will love as they hate the idea of "hand-holding", but it isn't a black-and-white concept - there is a middle ground where the game can both help you out and you can think for yourself how to solve situations. Other stealth games like Splinter Cell and Metal Gear Solid get that middle ground, while this unfortunately doesn't. People who dislike stealth games often criticise popular titles in the genre for being trial and error games - and yet, as a stealth fan who's played most games in the genre, I found this overly trial and error based. I don't think I've ever looked at a walkthrough as much as I did on this game as often I was left wondering how I was actually supposed to complete my objectives.Just to add insult to injury, the game is rife with bugs and glitches. You'll find yourself getting stuck in walls and tiny unexitable areas. You might experience a glitch where the camera is in a completely opposite direction to where your character is moving. Oh yeah, and the music in the intros is incredibly loud, so you've got that to enjoy whenever you launch the game.One area where Death to Spies does deserve credit is the map design - these maps are unusually large for stealth games and is a great change from dark, linear areas in many stealth games. However, there's nothing to do in these areas - if you want to complete the missions, there's always some linear path that is by far the simplest way to complete the missions. The game makes it far too difficult for you to actually use these open areas so you can complete a mission a different way from someone else.Despite all these issues, I still had fun with Death to Spies, and other stealth fans will feel the same. Credit has to go to the developers, as you can see they tried - the poor English grammar due to the game being a low-budget Russian title adds to the appeal a little. Unfortunately, the game is just plagued with too many flawed gameplay mechanics to make it enjoyable for the general gaming populace - and it's that which kills it.

												Agent 47 meets Commandos............ God, this game was hard! 'Death to Spies' puts you in the shoes of Russian counter-intelligence agent Semion Strogov who, whilst under interrogation, re-lives the covert operations he undertook as field agent. Mission objectives range from assassinating high-ranked enemy officers including spies, traitors and deserters, stealing secret documents and missile/weapon plans from scientific facilities, freeing (or assassinating) prisoners from concentration camps/lock-ups and blowing up bridges.The game is divided into ten missions, none of which are inter-linked in any way. Similar to other games of the stealth genre, disguises are an essential part of gameplay. The protagonist can change into any enemy (or civilian) uniform provided the fabric isn't damaged via acts of shooting or stabbing. Enemies, depending upon their ranks, can see through disguises so it is better to don the disguise of a high-rank official to pass unscathed. Gunplay and explosives are barely functional so don't expect to complete missions Rambo-style. Enemies converge from all sides the moment you're spotted and a huge barrage of them bring you down within seconds. A silenced revolver, muffled sniper-rifle, chloroform rag or knife are usually all that is required but useful ammo is scarce so essential targets have to be chosen wisely. Stunning enemies produces noise in a limited area around which could alert nearby adversaries. Knives can be thrown, with their trajectory depending upon the intended target's distance from you.An overhead radar map shows enemy positions with vision cones that exhibit their fields of view, which may either contract or elongate depending upon the protagonists posture. Whistling and smoke bombs are efficient methods to distract enemies, making them leave their positions. Running also produces noise which can result in an enemy sentry come investigating. Discovery of enemy bodies results in the alarm being raised which might fail the mission or consequently increase the number of highly-alert patrols.Environment interaction is extremely restrictive which makes missions all the more harder. I've often looked at windows/ledges and wished they could be opened or accessed in some way. Actions have to be timed perfectly to fulfill objectives. A few vehicles can be driven but they have little use unless driving them is part of the mission objective. Enemy bodies can be picked up and stoved inside boxes or trucks. Drinks can be poisoned on more than a few occasions. And locks can be picked through a fun, yet challenging mini-game.The game is gorgeous, if you don't go over the textures with a magnifying. There are a variety of locales which include wide open camps with buildings that can be entered, academic institutes, bombed-out towns, scientific facilities, hotels and an embassy. And the period attention to detail is flawless and extremely well done. Death to Spies is a deeply flawed game. What makes the game so frustrating at times is its restrictive gameplay elements. I've heard its sequel has improved upon a lot of areas. It requires some time and effort to calculate one's next move and the quicksave/quickload button would be abused mercilessly. But regardless, completing missions is a very rewarding experience.

Very much an unappreciated game. The levels are huge and well thought out, dispite the WW2 setting you get to sneak around some very nice and often quite exotic places including an old medieval castle straight out of Wolfenstein.Story:The story is about as good as its competitors in the genre. Think of the Hitman series up until Blood Money or Splinter Cell Chaos Theory. It is told through the main character reciting what he was doing behind enemy lines to a member of the KGB.Gameplay and Feel:The mechanics are solid and easy to get used to, levels have no element of randomness, they will behave the same way every time you restart them. While this may hurt replayability, it insures that you will not be screwed out of a successful run of the mission because the game didn't play by its own rules. The game comes with a full inventory management system which is what separates it from the Hitman series, you can only carry so much with so many pockets and things stored in your rucksack aren't immediately availible when you need them.Difficulty:I'm currently playing through the original Hitman: Codename 47 and I've completed Hitman 2: Silent Assassin, I would say that Death to Spies is easier than both of them but for the right reasons. Death to Spies does a great job of making sure you know what you need to be achieveing and even presents you with options for completing it, but the game doesn't play itself, it'll expect that you know how to get to where you need to be and you'll find yourself trying alternatives to the obvious. I found each level needed to be replayed about 2 to 4 times in order to get it right.Screw Stealth what else is there on offer?:The combat is pretty standard for a third person shooter of the day, no cover based shooting, no regenerating health, just you, your ammo, and your guns (think Sniper Elite). Guns sound nice and satisfying, and as you are fighting soldiers there is enough ammo in most levels to blast your way through. However in levels like the Hotel level you will find you are lacking firepower, and as your targets also lack their own personal army they will often run instead of going searching for you.What is the Tutorial like?:If you are new to the stealth/spy genre (not to be confused with pure stealth or stealth action) then I can confidently tell you that this isn't the deep end, but it's no paddling pool either. You'll find the tutorial pretty compresensive, but slow. I don't recommend skipping it even if you are a veteran of the Hitman or Splinter Cell games, as there are differences in mechanics that can open possibilities you wouldn't otherwise know about.

												This isn't for the faint of heart, or those easily frustrated, but if you're persistient enough it's a great stealth game and well worth a buy.The game is set in the context of an interrogation by a Russian intelligence officer of the protagonist, Sermion Strogov, as he recalls several missions he was involved in during WW2, in various different countries and with different goals. That isn't a spoiler, as the story is completely worthless and adds virtually nothing to the experience, it's just there to provide context. Your average Call of Duty game is more story-focused, so don't get this if you're looking for a deep, intriuging narrative experience. The level design and stealth system are both great. Levels are fairly varied, though a few missions are quite similar to one another. Trial and error is crucial - this is a very hard game, and you will die, or be discovered, or fail, a lot. Constantly dropping saves before doing anything risky at all is strongly advised - it is not a pleseant experience to have to reload back 5 minutes because you messed up avoiding a single guard. The health system is BRUTAL - no regenerating health or bullet sponge hero here. Strogov will die extremely quickly under fire, and there is no cover system so being discovered is essentialy a death sentence. Trying to just shoot everyone is pointless - you'll just die over and over again.The graphics still stand up in 2016 - it looks dated, but not awful.The controls are fairly bog-standard, and as someone who is primarily a console gamer I found them surprisingly good. However, you have to constantly correct Strogov's movement - for some reason, he walks diagonally by default. There are a few irritating animation glitches, but nothing gamebreaking and certainly not what other reviewers are sugguesting. Whether or not you get enjoyment out of this is basically down to how much failure you're willing to put up with. Just use your head, think what the logical solution is and you'll fail slightly less.

												It is true when people compare it to World War 2 Hitman. For example, most dead NPC's uniforms can be stolen and worn. Be warned though: This game is hard! I don't play many stealth games, but even on the lowest difficulty, the enemy's suspicion meter seems to increase very quickly and easily. One thing that makes stealth hard is that silent takedowns are hard to perform. When you crouch run behind the enemy to complete a takedown, their suspicion raises to full almost instantly. If you screw up here, the guard will turn around and quickly unload a mag and kill you. Another thing, which I have yet to see in another stealth game, is that when you are disguised and walk into a guard's "cone of vision", their cone of vision will follow you for a time because they are watching you, which could lead to the suspicion meter growing. Also, even when disguised, like in hitman, higher ranked NPC's will get suspicious of you faster.So far, I have not completely finished any level stealthily, as I'm not very patient. Instead, I use more of a run-and-gun playstyle with a small mix of stealth. So far there have not been any stealth requirement levels, but I expect one might come up. One thing to note if you plan on run and gunning is that the guns are realistic in terms of recoil. Holding down the trigger for more than 2 seconds will send your sights flying upwards, so you will find yourself clicking your left mouse button for every shot to be accurate, even on smgs.One con that I have noticed is that on multiple occasions, I would stealth kill one guard, and then the body gets found. Normal, right? Well, if there are five or six guards nearby, and they all see the body, they will run to it and start searching nearby. This system makes it so that at times, one body will make multiple guards clump around it and make easy targets of themselves. A couple of times, I've thrown a grenade at these groups and gotten multiple easy kills.Another problem is that if you camp in a one enterance area and hold your crosshairs on the door, wave after wave of guards will come running through the door idiotically, and run right into your spray. The only way they can prevent this, is if they see you, they will sometimes throw a grenade at you (Instant death, no matter how much health). The problem with this is if you are camping a door, you will most likely spray them down before they have time to throw a grenade. Because of this exploit, after several camping sessions, the door way would literally have a heap of 10 to 15 corpses.Another complaint I have is that when driving cars, going reverse will make the camera akwardly look down, then back. Also if you are reversing, the camera gets locked looking backwards, meaning that you cannot look in fromt of you while reversing, and vice-versa (this mechanic gets really annoying specially when you are trying to escape guards and can't look at them unless you are driving towards them.Also, if you are worried about content, you don't have to. At the time of me typing this, I have run-and-gunned my way through 3 missions in 9 hours (though I did make it my mission to kill all the nazis on all of those maps, even the ones that were out of the way) Plus, these levels are highly replayable, as you can choose your loadout at the start. You can choose any combination of equiptment you want through a weight system. Because of the difficulty in stealth, health system (no regen and only one full health medkit-sometimes none-per level) and shooting mechanics, this game really is hardcore stealth-action.For me, Death to Spies is a steal a $10 for any stealth, action, or WW2 fan!Oh, and also, lots of people say their game is buggy beyond playability, but I haven't experienced any game-breaking bugs yet. (I'm playing on a windows 10, i7 Laptop with Intel graphics)

												I have played hundreds of games in my life. Death to Spies is, without question, the absolute worst of these games.I say this with no sense of hyperbole. This game fails to implement even the most basic move and shoot gameplay elements competently.I challenge anyone to finish the tutorial without quitting in a fit of range. First, the way your avatar is facing and moving has only a tangential relationship to where the mouse is pointing. 												The obvious comparison to make with Death to Spies is Blood Money.Blood Money was an open sandbox, filled with various approaches and methods of killing that the developers had meticulously thought of and catered to. The player had the choice of experimenting, replaying, experimenting again, and treat it as a puzzle with many solutions. Blood Money and it's players enjoyed the fact that the developers gave it loving attention to detail.16 hours is not enough to fully explore Death to Spies but the initial impression I had of the game was less of an open sandbox to experiment in but a tough, and sometimes very tough, puzzle to crack with one optimal solution. If there's a noticeable difference at first, it's that unlike Blood Money, the missions are not set up at all for you to win through violence easily. In Blood Money, it's quite easy to kill everyone. In Death to Spies, unless you've got a handy doorway or corridor to abuse bot AI, you'll die in combat quite easily. A realistic number of guards patrol overlapping routes, often in groups of three or more. Towers will sometimes overlook these guards and static guards will sometimes place an additional layer of observation over roaming patrols. The guards will number in the dozens, far more than anything Blood Money will throw at you. Your weapons are also far less robust than the ones found in Hitman- there is no dual silenced pistol for you to mow down enemies while laughing- the best you get for handguns is a silenced revolver, and ammo is always scarce. Careful planning, observation, a bucketload of patience and good aiming skills, however, will get you far.The joy then, is to be found in seeing the minimap show a chunk of black dots instead of green ones, showing a successful penetration and exploitation of the whirling tango of green and red triangles. There's satisfaction to be found in finally finding a section of the map where the guards seem to lose sight of each other for just a bit, when you can violently ruin their day to make a gap in their patrol routes which you can use to sneak in further. The rest of the game after this is finding an officer's uniform to blend in and that's still filled with danger and close calls, as some NPCs won't be fooled by the disguise and will happily alert the dozens of armed guards next to you about your Russian heritage.It's worth noting that like Hitman, Death to Spies has also received attention to detail, only if it's been mostly apparent in the 16 hours I've played so far that the devs made a commendable effort to make the game look good even in 2015. Functional mirrors get an honourable mention here, as some modern triple AAA games still fail to have these. Sadly, there are also a few issues and bugs which do sour the experience, like issues with the camera bugging out temporarily, being stuck, bots being stuck and a few oddities like dropping a stunned person from your shoulders killing the person and unfortunately being the last diplomat you were allowed to kill before a diplomatic scandal happened.The audio is ok, although the dubbed translations are horrendous though tolerable (skippable). Expect nothing from ingame conversations or the like either. Level wise, the game does take you to quite a few different places and setpieces, which keeps things fresh enough to stop the 'get officers uniform- avoid red triangle' formula from becoming stale.For a dollar, this game was more than worth it. Gonna say that Death to Spies has less replayability than Hitman but if you want something Hitman like while waiting for the new one to come out, you should have bought it during the stealth sale it was pretty damn cheap.

												I can't help but compare Death to Spies and Hitman: Blood Money as both have a lot of similar mechanics and  gameplay aspects.So for those who've played Hitman: BM, it's the same except:* With Nazis* More confusing* Harder* Way more restrictive (mission failure conditions more cohercitive)* Larger, more open maps in general with more enemies* Yet less ways to complete a missionFor those who haven't played Blood Money (a game I strongly recommend)This game is about completing a mission, using of stealth and disguise, the latter being extensively important as the sheer number of enemies and some mission conditions (as well as the limited ammunition and firepower) make it impractical if not impossible to complete a mission by gunning your way through.So you have to wait for the correct enemy to get in a spot where you can take him down stealthly and steal their uniform to infiltrate enemy zones.If it's great on paper, it doesn't work very well in-game as weapons accuracy, enemies' detection and permitted actions/zones are sources of frustration.Sometimes, you're dead on target and your shot will miss, alerting the enemy that will probably sound the alarm, run away or alert his friends. Some enemies will just simply detect you (or not) depending on how the game feel. An enemy will be deaf and won't hear you breathing down his neck, or won't see you in his peripheral vision depsite you being in plain light, very visible. The very same enemy can detect you someties if you're out of his range (marked on the map), on a different elevation than him (you're uphill, he's downhill) and laying down in the grass with a camouflage suit.And even when you finally get a disguise, you're not out of trouble and will continiously be frustrated by the way the disguise system works.Once again, if it is good in theory, its application ruins it.Basically, when you are disguised you are authorized to be in certain area or perform certain action (an outer patrol isn't authorized in buildings), you won't fool commanding officers that are directly related to the disguise you're wearing (ex: the chief for outer patrols will spot you in an outer patrol uniform but the chief for inner patrols won't) and you need to carry the standard issue guns related to your uniform (while wearing a german guard uniform, wielding a Tokarev will get you spotted but an MP40 won't)I told you, it seems really interesting on paper.But in-game, while the interface will pop a message when equiping a weapon that doesn't fit the uniform, there's little to none indicator to what zones or actions are restricted to the uniform you just stole as most uniforms you can steal are by definition those of soldiers in secluded area and thus were not interacting or meeting other soldiers. How can you know if you can enter a building with your current uniform? The guard will tell you that you can't enter. If there's no guard, you enter and meet someone inside? They'll shoot you, no question asked. Same goes for most interactions. This makes the whole inflitration more based on trial and error rather than on observation.In brief, Death to Spies could have been so good, but ended up falling short on most of features.A waste of potential: 44/100
